issue.title: Move to JUnit5 for JUnit test execution

repository.name: jmeter
repository.description: Apache JMeter open-source load testing tool for analyzing and measuring the performance of a variety of services

issue.body:
Note: JUnit3 and JUnit4 tests can still be executed, however it makes sense to use JUnit5 for new tests

## Motivation and Context

JUnit5 has multiple API enhancements, so it makes sense to migrate to JUnit5.

Note: Gradle-JUnit5 chokes when it faces JUnit3 test suites with duplicate test names.
I'm not sure if it is a bug in JUnit or in Gradle, and I just add `Describable` implementation for the tests so they return different `uniqueId` values, so it works.
I think it is fine, and we hopefully could migrate those tests to JUnit5 or Spock alternatives.

body:
It looks like https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/06eeceb0978dd1059f7dd9ffd15c7552d7ad7553/junit-vintage-engine/src/main/java/org/junit/vintage/engine/execution/RunListenerAdapter.java#L110 is trying to "find parent".

What if `org.junit.vintage.engine.execution.RunListenerAdapter` analyzed `suite started / suite finished` events and maintained `current test identifier` accordingly?
Then it won't need to `find parent` as it would be ready.

Note: things like http://junit.sourceforge.net/junit3.8.1/javadoc/junit/extensions/ActiveTestSuite.html make it a bit complicated, so "current suite stack" have to be maintained in the thread-local variable.
Thanks for reporting! I'll have to take a closer look.

issue.title: WIP: use stack for tests in Vintage

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

This is a POC for https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2021

Unfortunately it does not fully work, however I might need to debug it a bit.

---

I hereby agree to the terms of the [JUnit Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/002a0052926ddee57cf90580fa49bc37e5a72427/CONTRIBUTING.md#junit-contributor-license-agreement).

---

### Definition of Done

- [ ] There are no TODOs left in the code
- [ ] Method [preconditions](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/api/org/junit/platform/commons/util/Preconditions.html) are checked and documented in the method's Javadoc
- [ ] [Coding conventions](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#coding-conventions) (e.g. for logging) have been followed
- [ ] Change is covered by [automated tests](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#tests) including corner cases, errors, and exception handling
- [ ] Public API has [Javadoc](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#javadoc) and [`@API` annotations](https://apiguardian-team.github.io/apiguardian/docs/current/api/org/apiguardian/api/API.html)
- [ ] Change is documented in the [User Guide](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/) and [Release Notes](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/#release-notes)
- [ ] All [continuous integration builds](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5#continuous-integration-builds) pass

body:
One of the culprits is Vintage is trying to discover all the tests early.

In other words:
1) It builds `VintageTestDescriptor` entities based on test `Description` objects
2) Then it starts executing tests, and it tries to reuse "already known `VintageTestDescriptor` objects"

That does not work when multiple different tests have the same (in terms of `equals`) `Descriptions`.
In other words, if `reference equality` is desired, then Vintage can't really provision `VintageTestDescriptor` in advance because it will get **different**  `Description` objects.

On top of that `JUnit38ClassRunner` does not really maintain `Test->Description` mapping, thus "reference equality" can't really be safely used there.

It looks like the options are:
1) Rewrite TestSuite-based tests into JUnit5
2) Retrofit `Description#getParent` to JUnit4. This might work for trivial cases, however custom JUnit runners might be not that compatible because they don't know that `Description` should include parent
3) Retrofit `suite started/stopped` events to JUnit4's `TestSuite` and other "in-the-box runners". That would improve Vintage compatibility with existing runners.

@marcphilipp , what do you think?

> One of the culprits is Vintage is trying to discover all the tests early.

That's how the JUnit Platform works so I don't see a way around that.

> In other words, if reference equality is desired, then Vintage can't really provision VintageTestDescriptor in advance because it will get different Description objects.

Reference equality is only used as a last resort. Equality for objects should be enough except for edge cases.

> It looks like the options are

I first need to take a closer look before discussing potential solutions. ðŸ™‚
Here's another idea: if we cannot find a unique `Description` with `equals()` nor with reference equality, we could use the first ~non-started~ non-finished/skipped one from the list.

>we could use the first non-started non-finished/skipped one from the list

That does not work for randomized / multi-threaded test execution order.

> Equality for objects should be enough except for edge cases.

Well. That depends. Javadocs for RunListener [explicitly mention](https://junit.org/junit4/javadoc/4.12/org/junit/runner/notification/RunListener.html#testFailure(org.junit.runner.notification.Failure)) reference equality.

>That's how the JUnit Platform works so I don't see a way around that.

JUnit Platform allows for dynamic test registration.
So discovery could be just ignored, and it could assume that all the tests are dynamic.

Just in case: I tried that as well, and the issue with that approach is JUnit3-4 does not provide enough information to recognize "the current suite/subsuite/subsubsuite name". That is why N3 in my list is re improving JUnit4 code so it provides better visibility on the test execution.

Just in case: I've rewritten the tests that used `ActiveTestSuite` to JUnit5, and I've added lots of dummy `implements Descriptable` so the tests produce unique ids.

It breaks UI in IDEA (as IDEA can no longer associate test names with test ids), however it seems "good enough" as then we could gradually migrate tests to `@parameterized` or something like that.

I'm not sure "same" was intended to mean reference equality. If it was, `JUnit38ClassRunner` does not behave accordingly since it does not pass the same `Description` instance to `testFinished` that it passed to `testStarted`.

issue.title: Improve handling of duplicate Descriptions

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
Some runners don't memoize Description instances and even pass different
instances when invoking testStarted and testFinished. This makes it
particularly difficult when there are multiple equal Description
instances in a Runner.

Prior to this commit, such cases were deemed unresolvable which lead to
multiple dynamic TestDescriptors with the same unique ID being reported
which is a violation of the contract of TestExecutionListener.

Now, we assume the testStarted/testSkipped event for a Description with
multiple equal Descriptions is referring to the first Description that
hasn't yet been started or skipped. The corresponding TestDescriptor is
then reported as started/skipped. When testFinished is called for such
a Description, we check whether the same thread has previously reported
an equal Description as started. If so, we report the corresponding
TestDescriptor as finished.

Fixes #2021.

---

I hereby agree to the terms of the [JUnit Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/002a0052926ddee57cf90580fa49bc37e5a72427/CONTRIBUTING.md#junit-contributor-license-agreement).

---

### Definition of Done

- [x] There are no TODOs left in the code
- [x] Method [preconditions](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/api/org/junit/platform/commons/util/Preconditions.html) are checked and documented in the method's Javadoc
- [x] [Coding conventions](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#coding-conventions) (e.g. for logging) have been followed
- [x] Change is covered by [automated tests](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#tests) including corner cases, errors, and exception handling
- [x] Public API has [Javadoc](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#javadoc) and [`@API` annotations](https://apiguardian-team.github.io/apiguardian/docs/current/api/org/apiguardian/api/API.html)
- [x] Change is documented in the [User Guide](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/) and [Release Notes](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/#release-notes)
- [x] All [continuous integration builds](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5#continuous-integration-builds) pass
